critique: This document pertains to the National Industrial Recovery Act of 1933 and delegates authority to the Administrator for Industrial Recovery to modify or grant exceptions to agreements made under the Act, in cases where compliance would cause undue hardship. It does not directly address immigration, civil liberties, or social inclusion. The document seems to expand executive power by delegating authority, and it leans towards government intervention in the economy. It does not directly relate to federalism.
